div1.p:
Please forgive me for my long delay in replying to your friendly and generous letter. Various things of a different nature have withheld me from my correspondence. You are very kind to offer to write something about my work but I doubt whether it is worth while to say muchanything — my output has been so slight. Beside the Abelard there were two earlier books but they are out of print and I have no copies. The only things that I feel like acknowledging are some lyrical pieces which have never been collected. One of them The Lesser Children I still feel was worth
34
while. It was published in the Atlantic in September 1905. You may detect some languor in this. It is not due to my attitude toward Poetry but merely to my own work — and in fact to nearly everyone else's in America. I feel more and more that the real thing is yet to be done. None of us have touched it and everything seems sad in comparison with what should be. However I will not depress you with a repetition of what you doubtless yourself feel.

Since you are good enough to offer to do the article I will help you in whatever way you may require if I can. There is absolutely nothing of interest about my biography except what could be culled from Who's Who. I have no photograph at present but if I can secure one later and if you still shall want it I will
35
201
send it to you. I remember our luncheon together with pleasure. You have since been married. I congratulate you and with heartiest good wishes I am
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours
Ridgely Torrence
Mr. John G. Neihardt
